Award.AwardTitle: CPS: Small: A Framework for Validation and Monitoring of Robotic Surgery Systems

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
Complex surgical procedures in hospitals are increasingly aided by robotic surgery systems, often at the request of patients. These systems allow greatly increased precision, reach and flexibility to the surgeon. However, their powerful capabilities entail substantial system complexity in both hardware and software. The high probability of serious injuries should a malfunction occur calls for rigorous assessment and monitoring of the reliability and safety of these cyber-physical systems.

In this research project, a framework for assessing and monitoring the reliability and safety of robotic surgery systems during development, field testing, and general deployment is being developed. The proposed framework complements existing techniques used in earlier phases of validation by taking into account how surgeons actually use a robotic surgery system, how it is affected by operating conditions, and how its observable behavior is related to its hardware and software dynamics.

Before deployment, this framework uses accurate simulations to assess pre-clinical reliability. After deployment, the framework uses data collection through online monitoring of the system as it is being used in the field, followed by analysis to obtain assessments of operational reliability and safety. The collected data is also used to improve the simulations for future testing. The framework also aims to support post-market surveillance of these systems by providing a workable basis for reassessing reliability and safety properties after system maintenance.

The developed tools and methods will also have applications in the validation of safety and reliability of other medical devices with embedded software and other cyber-physical systems in general.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Robotic surgery systems are cyber-physical systems that promise to transform common surgical procedures. These systems allow greatly increased precision, reach and flexibility to the surgeon. However, their powerful capabilities entail substantial system complexity in both hardware and software. The high probability of serious injuries should a malfunction occur calls for rigorous assessment and monitoring of the reliability and safety of these cyber-physical systems.

This research study focused on development of a framework for assessing and monitoring the reliability and safety of robotic surgery systems during development, field testing, and general deployment. The proposed framework complements existing techniques used in earlier phases of validation by taking into account how the robotic surgery system is actually used, how it is affected by operating conditions, and how its observable behavior is related to its hardware and software dynamics. Specifically, the major aspects of the project were: (1) development of hardware and software mechanisms to effectively detect adverse and anomalous system events and collect internal system data that is relevant to predicting their occurrences and to locating their causes; (2) development of sampling?based techniques that are suitable for accurately estimating the probabilities of adverse and anomalous events of specified types and severity levels, and helping engineers localize the hardware and software faults that cause adverse and anomalous events; and, (3) evaluation of the proposed framework under realistic conditions.  .

The primary outcomes of the research activities has been the development of i) new machine learning based methods for detecting failure in medical cyber-physical systems, ii) new methods for fault localization in embedded controllers and numerical software, and iii) a novel robotic image-guided surgery system prototype. The investigators have also developed iv) a computationally efficient model of needle-tissue interaction, which can be used for surgical simulation as well as development of algorithms for surgical planning and robotic motion control algorithms, v) probabilistic algorithms for active localization of target and needle in robotic image-guided intervention systems, and vi) advanced robotic motion control, planning, and sensing algorithms for robotic surgical systems.

Educational activities conducted as part of the project span training of graduate and undergraduate students in robotics and interdisciplinary research, educational outreach to the technical community and the broader public, and graduate level course development.
